description: Borrowed from French dissociation, from Latin dissociātiō.

entries.meaning: The act of dissociating or disuniting; a state of separation; disunion.
(chemistry) The process by which a compound body breaks up into simpler constituents; said particularly of the action of heat on gaseous or volatile substances.
examples: the dissociation of the sulphur molecules
the dissociation of ammonium chloride into hydrochloric acid and ammonia

entries.meaning: (psychology) A defence mechanism where certain thoughts or mental processes are compartmentalised in order to avoid emotional stress to the conscious mind.
examples: Project MONARCH could be best described as a form of structured dissociation and occultic integration, carried out in order to compartmentalize the mind into multiple personalities within a systematic framework.
